item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
@nahuelzn My apologies for being unclear on tone. I meant it as a discussion of the wider impacts of AI on society. If the AI labs are right about the technology, they are still likely wrong about the implications & we should worry about that. It can be hard to get tone right in a post

@nahuelzn My apologies for being unclear on tone. I meant it as a discussion of the wider impacts of AI on society. If the AI labs are right about the technology, they are still likely wrong about the implications & we should worry about that. It can be hard to get tone right in a post

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

Nahuel Lanz贸n @nahuelzn

@emollick I re-read the post to see if I misread it and still think it sounds like "look, AI ceos finally were right and we ignored them, now we're in a hurry". Even when your own opinion was that framing the discussion about jobs in that way were harmful and provided AI skeptics an angle

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
The failure to articulate non-ominous visions of the future (even Machines of Loving Grace fails to explain what life would actually be like) is going to be a problem.

The failure to articulate non-ominous visions of the future (even Machines of Loving Grace fails to explain what life would actually be like) is going to be a problem.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

The CEOs of the AI labs have spent the last two years ominously discussing massive future job losses, and were mostly ignored. As AI becomes more salient, workers and policymakers are going to start taking that kind of talk seriously, with big implications for the industry.

item.title: Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo)
item.description:
@flossberg @dagorenouf Bankruptcy rates tell you nothing about healthcare quality.

Business and individual bankruptcies are also the highest in the US compared to other countries, but its still richer and more conducive to business success than the other places with lower failure rates.

@flossberg @dagorenouf Bankruptcy rates tell you nothing about healthcare quality.

Business and individual bankruptcies are also the highest in the US compared to other countries, but its still richer and more conducive to business success than the other places with lower failure rates.

— Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

Gunther vom Floberg 吼佛叼 @flossberg

@dvassallo @dagorenouf Completely delusional take when some hundreds of thousands file for bankruptcy due to medical bills in the USA every year. A rare occurrence in Europe.

Also, education still matters, e.g. if you have non-academic parents free school gives you a chance they won't give you...

item.title: Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo)
item.description:
The outcome numbers look at population averages so they get skewed by people who neglect their health, dont seek treatment, seek it too late, antivaxers, bad neighborhoods, and other things. If youre not that person, population averages dont matter to you individually.

If Bezos were to need some healthcare, do you think hell go abroad? He can. But probably he wont.

The outcome numbers look at population averages so they get skewed by people who neglect their health, dont seek treatment, seek it too late, antivaxers, bad neighborhoods, and other things. If youre not that person, population averages dont matter to you individually.

If Bezos were to need some healthcare, do you think hell go abroad? He can. But probably he wont.

— Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

inthezone @inthezoneuk

@dvassallo @dagorenouf Its the most expensive system in the world. Even with insurance, many have to pay thousands in excess, all assuming your condition is covered. Hundreds of thousands go bankrupt each year due to medical bills.

My cousin who works as a nurse in the American system, stated that

item.title: Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo)
item.description:
@dagorenouf US healthcare is best in the world. You just have to pay for it. If youre poor, its free. If youre old, its free as well. If youre almost poor, its subsidized. But you can afford it.

Education doesnt matter anymore. Anyone can learn anything from anywhere in the world.

@dagorenouf US healthcare is best in the world. You just have to pay for it. If youre poor, its free. If youre old, its free as well. If youre almost poor, its subsidized. But you can afford it.

Education doesnt matter anymore. Anyone can learn anything from anywhere in the world.

— Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

Dagobert - Corporate sellout @dagorenouf

I dont want to stay in France because of huge taxes and lack of hustle energy.
I cant move to Asia because I need overlap with US time zone for my sales job.
Im scared to move to US while I build a family because healthcare and education is shit

Its about cost structure inversion.

In product companies, tokens start to rival S&M.

In services companies, tokens start to rival payroll.

When compute scales faster than people, youre operating differently.

looks really useful if you're into optimising RL algos/infra on small models. https://t.co/Zr8ecAnxGS

— tokenbender (@tokenbender) February 22, 2026

Quoting:

Richard Zhuang @RichardZ412

Terminal-Bench is a leading benchmark for agents. Unfortunately its hard: most small coding agents get very low scores on TB2, so training/system ablations look flat - you can't tell what's working.

Announcing OpenThoughts-TBLite - 100 curated TB2-style tasks, https://t.co/ECABWjTcgD

Quoting:

Vaibhav Tulsyan @xennygrimmato_

Now that Taalas has blown up, I think people should read the PIM-GPT paper.
PIM-GPT leverages DRAM-based PIM designs for executing multiply-accumulate (MAC) operations directly in the DRAM chips, eliminating the need to move matrix data off-chip. Non-linear functions and data https://t.co/fNVvTPDlez https://t.co/GUIniRFoaB

Replying to:

swyx @swyx

yesterday we chatted with @martin_casado and @sarahdingwang on the pod and he happened to do basic math on the logic of asics

today @taalas_inc launched their HC1 asic that can inference 17k tok/s. Sure, it's a shitty 3.1 8B today which is a 1.5 year gap.

But read the details https://t.co/xmMfsHoGMl https://t.co/4wCffRdQsm

item.title: tokenbender (@tokenbender)
item.description:
the trajectory is set - the models would learn to write a minimal scaffold given any task. humans would teach how to whitelist/blacklist based on policies. everything to descend the reliability optim hill.

until the self-policing also gets absorbed in the "system" itself.

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
@Afinetheorem I like this counterexample, puts some emphasis on the need for the rising tide of AI to lift all boats.

@Afinetheorem I like this counterexample, puts some emphasis on the need for the rising tide of AI to lift all boats.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

Kevin A. Bryan @Afinetheorem

When we go from 50% ag workers to 1% over two generations, we don't see any change in overall employment, wages go up, and the people who get rich are not the people who owned farmland or John Deere in 1920. This is a possible AI future! 2/2
item.content:encoded:
@Afinetheorem I like this counterexample, puts some emphasis on the need for the rising tide of AI to lift all boats.

@Afinetheorem I like this counterexample, puts some emphasis on the need for the rising tide of AI to lift all boats.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

Kevin A. Bryan @Afinetheorem

When we go from 50% ag workers to 1% over two generations, we don't see any change in overall employment, wages go up, and the people who get rich are not the people who owned farmland or John Deere in 1920. This is a possible AI future! 2/2

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
@algekalipso But. isn't qualia too tightly constrained by evolutionary history?

we see distinctions in qualia space because they've helped us in our evolutionary past.

Having said that, the redness of red will remain a big mystery to me.

Indeed! I struggle to even conceive

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
If you have a large pool of people, their "jaggedness" cancels out because they have diverse skills and talents. 1000 agents of the same model are not the same thing, they have the same weakspots and, potentially, are more vulnerable to groupthink-like problems than humans.

If you have a large pool of people, their "jaggedness" cancels out because they have diverse skills and talents. 1000 agents of the same model are not the same thing, they have the same weakspots and, potentially, are more vulnerable to groupthink-like problems than humans.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 22, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Jaggedness remains a key feature of LLMs & I have yet to see a clearly articulated argument about why it will disappear. A jagged general intelligence (not quite an oxymoron, as humans are too) still creates lots of bottlenecks that require people & slow many kinds of take-off.
item.content:encoded:

item.description:
@alexoakdev No changes recently. Opus 4.6 and Sonnet 4.6 are more intelligent and use more tokens than previous models. If you want less thinking and lower token usage, run /model and set effort to low or medium.

@alexoakdev No changes recently. Opus 4.6 and Sonnet 4.6 are more intelligent and use more tokens than previous models. If you want less thinking and lower token usage, run /model and set effort to low or medium.

Alex Oak @alexoakdev

Does anybody else feel like Claude Code keeps nerfing their usage limits???

item.title: Alex Volkov (Thursd/AI) (@altryne)
item.description:
Thank you for working on this, I've been testing it and here's a bunch of feedback:
- Hard to configure, even for the bots, they dont know about it

- Cannot set custom voice models: The modelByChannel is sorely needed to allow faster models on voice channels (can't wait to try out spark) but is rejected by schema validator? Looks like it didn't end up in the schema validator

- Support for other TTS models is impossible, via plugins of otherwise. I tried to setup with @inworld_ai TTS and bubkis, it's not supported. would love to open up support for other TTS models

- Cannot set custom instructions for voice, there's no metadata injected for the LLM to know it's now "talking" vs "texting". there needs to be, because LLMs spit out a SHIT ton of text, and for voice it's boring to listen to

- Streaming! Very very important to have streming and chunking enabled for true speed.

I'm sure @kwindla has a bunch of other ideas of how to improve this, but I'd love to see the bot conversation abilities improve, this is a great start!

Thank you for working on this, I've been testing it and here's a bunch of feedback:
- Hard to configure, even for the bots, they dont know about it

- Cannot set custom voice models: The modelByChannel is sorely needed to allow faster models on voice channels (can't wait to try out spark) but is rejected by schema validator? Looks like it didn't end up in the schema validator

- Support for other TTS models is impossible, via plugins of otherwise. I tried to setup with @inworld_ai TTS and bubkis, it's not supported. would love to open up support for other TTS models

- Cannot set custom instructions for voice, there's no metadata injected for the LLM to know it's now "talking" vs "texting". there needs to be, because LLMs spit out a SHIT ton of text, and for voice it's boring to listen to

- Streaming! Very very important to have streming and chunking enabled for true speed.

I'm sure @kwindla has a bunch of other ideas of how to improve this, but I'd love to see the bot conversation abilities improve, this is a great start!

— Alex Volkov (Thursd/AI) (@altryne) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Shadow @4shad0wed

Ok so I spent like 13 hours yesterday and I have some really fun stuff for Discord from both myself and several contributors. Long list incoming:

猸 You can now VC with your agents in servers! Use either the /vc command, or set specific channels in your config that your agent https://t.co/CB4jf4iXbF

- Cannot set custom instructions for voice, there's no metadata injected for the LLM to know it's now "talking" vs "texting". there needs to be, because LLMs spit out a SHIT ton of text, and for voice it's boring to listen to

I'm sure @kwindla has a bunch of other ideas of how to improve this, but I'd love to see the bot conversation abilities improve, this is a great start!

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
This account keeps posting older papers as new releases with AI generated commentary, but this paper is from June 2025, where it sparked some interesting debate but basically turned out to not be that relevant in the last year as models improved. https://t.co/es7yFdrhE0 https://t.co/byrDb8rEeo

This account keeps posting older papers as new releases with AI generated commentary, but this paper is from June 2025, where it sparked some interesting debate but basically turned out to not be that relevant in the last year as models improved. https://t.co/es7yFdrhE0 https://t.co/byrDb8rEeo

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 21, 2026

Quoting:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Every call I have had this week has had someone ask a question about the Apple paper.

I think its worth reflecting on why any time a "AI must fail" paper comes out (also: model collapse), it gets a lot of buzz & why the many "AI does this well" papers don't. Discomfort with AI?

item.title: Jeremy Howard (@jeremyphoward)
item.description:
@kcosr @PiotrCzapla Giving vendors a free pass just because their oversights can be fixed by every single user adding additional safeguards is not how secure systems are built.

@kcosr @PiotrCzapla Giving vendors a free pass just because their oversights can be fixed by every single user adding additional safeguards is not how secure systems are built.

— Jeremy Howard (@jeremyphoward) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Jeremy Howard @jeremyphoward

@kcosr @PiotrCzapla Respectfully, I think you misunderstood it. The article clearly shows how the issue can be fixed both client-side and LLM-side, and suggests both.

Structured LLM tool call requests can be easily correctly and fully validated on both ends, but OpenAI does it server-side.

item.description:

@kcosr @PiotrCzapla Respectfully, I think you misunderstood it. The article clearly shows how the issue can be fixed both client-side and LLM-side, and suggests both.

Structured LLM tool call requests can be easily correctly and fully validated on both ends, but OpenAI does it server-side.

— Jeremy Howard (@jeremyphoward) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Kevin @kcosr

@jeremyphoward @PiotrCzapla I've read it, and respectfully, I think the focus is misplaced. LLM output should be treated as untrusted input. You wouldn't disable validation in your backend and blame the browser for letting bad data from the user through.

@rohanpaul_ai Creator of NanoClaw here, thanks for sharing.

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
A good Claw can already do most lightweight phone doing work, and those agents are unoptimized messes right now.

Makes me wonder what Apple is giving up by bowing out of the LLM building world. I suspect a lot more than they thought.

A good Claw can already do most lightweight phone doing work, and those agents are unoptimized messes right now.

Makes me wonder what Apple is giving up by bowing out of the LLM building world. I suspect a lot more than they thought.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

I dont see as much discussion over the nature of phone OSs in the era of AI but it feels like it will change. I basically want to use my phone for two things (a) connect to legacy apps & (b) do stuff.

Pretty convinced that for all (b) tasks I would rather talk to a good agent

I dont see as much discussion over the nature of phone OSs in the era of AI but it feels like it will change. I basically want to use my phone for two things (a) connect to legacy apps & (b) do stuff.

Pretty convinced that for all (b) tasks I would rather talk to a good agent

item.title: Boris Cherny (@bcherny)
item.description:
I generally use subagents with worktrees to do parallelizable work that doesnt conflict, eg. large codebase migrations where each agent gets a few folders. Its been a big speed up for that.

Probably a little more we can do to make the ux smooth for non-independent work, though currently I think it will just work and the main agent would resolve conflicts fine. Enabling agent teams may help also, so the agents can better coordinate their work when it overlaps

I generally use subagents with worktrees to do parallelizable work that doesnt conflict, eg. large codebase migrations where each agent gets a few folders. Its been a big speed up for that.

Probably a little more we can do to make the ux smooth for non-independent work, though currently I think it will just work and the main agent would resolve conflicts fine. Enabling agent teams may help also, so the agents can better coordinate their work when it overlaps

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Addy Osmani @addyosmani

@bcherny Happy to see this ship! Parallel agents are great but merge conflict resolution has been a manual process. Do you do anything to auto resolve these once the agents are done working?

but still gets difficult with pages with multiple figures or big tables.

@staghado yes i used the q8 version, it is quite good, close to full agentic ocr in few cases.

but still gets difficult with pages with multiple figures or big tables.

— tokenbender (@tokenbender) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

staghado @staghado

@tokenbender i have made some choices to improve speed that might affect a general pdf to markdown performance: 1/ limited the image resolution to half what its trained for and 2/ quantized the model to 4-bit for faster generation.
both these affect results significantly sadly!

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
A simple reminder.

For Indias currency to remain valuable, India must have something valuable to export to the world. Historically its has been cheap labour and growth story but when western countries replace that with AI and discover high growth industries in their home ground, rupee value could drop significantly and evening India imports would become dramatically costly.

And we do import a lot! Oil, electronics, gold. All of it would become expensive.

This is why India must remain competitive on the global stage. Our population will quickly go from being a growth driver to being a liability if we dont ramp up on innovation and R&D.

Its honestly an existential matter for the countrys future.

Its honestly an existential matter for the countrys future.

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 21, 2026

item.title: Boris Cherny (@bcherny)
item.description:
Personally, Ive been finding subagent worktrees useful for 1-shotting large batch changes like codebase-wide code migrations. Previously, these would have been a single plan (less well executed), a Ralph loop (doesnt always work), a custom harness with agent SDK in a python loop (more code), or a team.

I dont use worktree as much but the team is split roughly 50/50 with half using worktrees and half preferring multiple git checkouts or multiple tabs in the Desktop app.

Personally, Ive been finding subagent worktrees useful for 1-shotting large batch changes like codebase-wide code migrations. Previously, these would have been a single plan (less well executed), a Ralph loop (doesnt always work), a custom harness with agent SDK in a python loop (more code), or a team.

I dont use worktree as much but the team is split roughly 50/50 with half using worktrees and half preferring multiple git checkouts or multiple tabs in the Desktop app.

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Numman Ali @nummanali

I have a few problems with worktrees:
- you need to reinstall everything
- you need to clean up after
- conflicts arise again on merge
- different agents handle it their way

I suppose for incremental changes that are tight this makes sense

But isnt that going backwards? https://t.co/vQTkurMwLz

item.title: swyx (@swyx)
item.description:
further analysis https://t.co/VKO9mHxE5T

further analysis https://t.co/VKO9mHxE5T

— swyx (@swyx) February 21, 2026

Quoting:

Andrej Karpathy @karpathy

Bought a new Mac mini to properly tinker with claws over the weekend. The apple store person told me they are selling like hotcakes and everyone is confused :)

I'm definitely a bit sus'd to run OpenClaw specifically - giving my private data/keys to 400K lines of vibe coded

Replying to:

swyx @swyx

NanoClaw fixes a couple complaints people have about OpenClaw - it's a minimal, hackable reproduction (700LOC), that uses Apple Containers for sandboxing/security.

currently using deepwiki codemaps to explore the codebase. highly recommend interactive learning with on-demand Q&A https://t.co/ijROZ3tB4B https://t.co/QSB8VtR8zx

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
@robinhanson by inference, therefore, we should bias towards concluding that phenomenal consciousness must have an adaptive role

epiphenomena is a dead-end when it comes to empirical investigation, so you might as well assume causalty

@robinhanson by inference, therefore, we should bias towards concluding that phenomenal consciousness must have an adaptive role

epiphenomena is a dead-end when it comes to empirical investigation, so you might as well assume causalty

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Robin Hanson @robinhanson

@paraschopra If, by the usual assumption, we could have all the same physical systems and processes with or without phenomenal consciousness, how could it possibly help animals to be adaptive to have it, vs not have it?

item.title: Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo)
item.description:

— Daniel Vassallo (@dvassallo) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

JD Vance @JDVance

Today, the Supreme Court decided that Congress, despite giving the president the ability to "regulate imports", didn't actually mean it. This is lawlessness from the Court, plain and simple. And its only effect will be to make it harder for the president to protect American

item.title: swyx (@swyx)
item.description:
yesterday we chatted with @martin_casado and @sarahdingwang on the pod and he happened to do basic math on the logic of asics

today @taalas_inc launched their HC1 asic that can inference 17k tok/s. Sure, it's a shitty 3.1 8B today which is a 1.5 year gap.

But read the details to the HC2 this winter, and do the math this timeline will converge to 0 in the next 2 years.

Build accordingly.

item.title: Boris Cherny (@bcherny)
item.description:
@udaysy Yep, if there's no code changes (so you don't lose your changes). After you exit a session, we'll prompt you whether you want to keep the worktree around.

@udaysy Yep, if there's no code changes (so you don't lose your changes). After you exit a session, we'll prompt you whether you want to keep the worktree around.

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Uday Yatnalli @udaysy

@bcherny the subagent isolation is the part i care about most. running parallel agents on the same repo without merge conflicts was painful before this. does the CLI version auto-cleanup worktrees when agents finish?
item.content:encoded:
@udaysy Yep, if there's no code changes (so you don't lose your changes). After you exit a session, we'll prompt you whether you want to keep the worktree around.

@byzatine_zeno It shouldn't be possible because Anthropic are very careful about locking down the data exfiltration leg of the lethal trifecta - also there's nothing unique about GitHub here, could equally well be injected by a fetched URL or a document upload

@byzatine_zeno It shouldn't be possible because Anthropic are very careful about locking down the data exfiltration leg of the lethal trifecta - also there's nothing unique about GitHub here, could equally well be injected by a fetched URL or a document upload

raahel @byzatine_zeno

item.title: Boris Cherny (@bcherny)
item.description:
@chazza Worktrees stay scoped to the agent that started them, but stay around after if the main agent wants to read them

@chazza Worktrees stay scoped to the agent that started them, but stay around after if the main agent wants to read them

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Charlie J @chazza

@bcherny Ive never used worktrees before, I assume once the agent is done it gets merged as such into the main branch youre working on, and the workbench gets deleted?

And then other agents deal with the merge conflicts?
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Boris Cherny (@bcherny)
item.description:
1/ Use claude --worktree for isolation

To run Claude Code in its own git worktree, just start it with the --worktree option. You can also name your worktree, or have Claude name it for you.

Use this to run multiple parallel Claude Code sessions in the same git repo, without the code edits clobbering each other.

You can also pass the --tmux flag to launch Claude in its own Tmux session.

1/ Use claude --worktree for isolation

To run Claude Code in its own git worktree, just start it with the --worktree option. You can also name your worktree, or have Claude name it for you.

Use this to run multiple parallel Claude Code sessions in the same git repo, without the code edits clobbering each other.

You can also pass the --tmux flag to launch Claude in its own Tmux session.

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 21, 2026

Replying to:

Boris Cherny @bcherny

Introducing: built-in git worktree support for Claude Code

Now, agents can run in parallel without interfering with one other. Each agent gets its own worktree and can work independently.

The Claude Code Desktop app has had built-in support for worktrees for a while, and now https://t.co/cjOXhUDL0i
item.content:encoded:
1/ Use claude --worktree for isolation

To run Claude Code in its own git worktree, just start it with the --worktree option. You can also name your worktree, or have Claude name it for you.

Use this to run multiple parallel Claude Code sessions in the same git repo, without the code edits clobbering each other.

You can also pass the --tmux flag to launch Claude in its own Tmux session.

1/ Use claude --worktree for isolation

To run Claude Code in its own git worktree, just start it with the --worktree option. You can also name your worktree, or have Claude name it for you.

Use this to run multiple parallel Claude Code sessions in the same git repo, without the code edits clobbering each other.

You can also pass the --tmux flag to launch Claude in its own Tmux session.

item.title: Boris Cherny (@bcherny)
item.description:
Introducing: built-in git worktree support for Claude Code

Now, agents can run in parallel without interfering with one other. Each agent gets its own worktree and can work independently.

The Claude Code Desktop app has had built-in support for worktrees for a while, and now we're bringing it to CLI too.

Learn more about worktrees: https://t.co/JFkD2DrAmT

Introducing: built-in git worktree support for Claude Code

Now, agents can run in parallel without interfering with one other. Each agent gets its own worktree and can work independently.

The Claude Code Desktop app has had built-in support for worktrees for a while, and now we're bringing it to CLI too.

Learn more about worktrees: https://t.co/JFkD2DrAmT

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 21, 2026
item.content:encoded:
Introducing: built-in git worktree support for Claude Code

Now, agents can run in parallel without interfering with one other. Each agent gets its own worktree and can work independently.

The Claude Code Desktop app has had built-in support for worktrees for a while, and now we're bringing it to CLI too.

Learn more about worktrees: https://t.co/JFkD2DrAmT

Introducing: built-in git worktree support for Claude Code

Now, agents can run in parallel without interfering with one other. Each agent gets its own worktree and can work independently.

The Claude Code Desktop app has had built-in support for worktrees for a while, and now we're bringing it to CLI too.

Learn more about worktrees: https://t.co/JFkD2DrAmT

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 21, 2026

item.title: swyx (@swyx)
item.description:
## the egocentric fallacy: "the most important part of a trend will happen to be right now when i randomly decide to care a lot about it because of some dude's post"

just to punch strawmen with Han (whom i love), this meta-principle of "choose the laggards in hopes they catch up" is a noob mistake and has a lower chance of working than most people are trained to appreciate (because they fundamentally want to believe in equality when capitalism fundamentally does not).

generation after generation of investors from Thiel to @Chamath have learned painful lessons to double down on winners rather than do relative value trades.

a simple thought exercise is to ask if the Software Engineering number goes up to 80% or 90% in the next 5 years would you be better of working on Back Office Automation? (no, the answer is no, some folks are so capitalism illiterate you need that to be spelled out) . So then if we just zoomed from 10 to 50% in the last 2 years, it is actually a classic egotistical fallacy that this exact moment is when AI x SWE peaked and it's all relative downside from here vs other domains, which is what is implied by the chart below: who are you, who are we, what evidence do you have, to say we are anywhere even close to done on the largest product market fit we've seen in software business history?

@nlw has been echoing my thoughts here - kode is the lions share of agi and basically by betting on anything else you may well be rich and you may well be happier and you may well have much more positive social impact on the world.... but do not confuse that for having higher expected value.

@nlw has been echoing my thoughts here - kode is the lions share of agi and basically by betting on anything else you may well be rich and you may well be happier and you may well have much more positive social impact on the world.... but do not confuse that for having higher expected value.

— swyx (@swyx) February 21, 2026

Quoting:

Han Wang @handotdev

what I would be working on if I started another company today https://t.co/kKDFxcbtZv https://t.co/7dpDyiHAW6

item.title: Jeremy Howard (@jeremyphoward)
item.description:
@Isinlor @OpenAI It's actually easily fixed server-side, and OpenAI already do it correctly.

@Isinlor @OpenAI It's actually easily fixed server-side, and OpenAI already do it correctly.

— Jeremy Howard (@jeremyphoward) February 20, 2026

Replying to:

Tomasz Darmetko 叼别吼吼 @Isinlor

@jeremyphoward @OpenAI Why are the agents not sandboxed? We have wonderful tools to do it - VMs, containers of various types - we can have very tight control on what any code can do inside a sandbox. If you don't have a proper sandbox, then there are no restrictions. The models are wicked smart.

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
At this point, in any call, it is likely someone is AI transcribing, whether they tell you (& whether that is legal or not).

We really need clear norms & rules about how these transcripts can be used, since AI makes them searchable/applicable in lots of ways no one ever expected

item.title: Chris Albon (@chrisalbon)
item.description:
One annoying thing about agentic programming is that it doesn't understand when I am giving a hand-wavy answer.

Me: "The PDF you made was one page, it should be way longer, like 50 pages or something"

Codex: "Got it, I will make a PDF of exactly 50 pages"

One annoying thing about agentic programming is that it doesn't understand when I am giving a hand-wavy answer.

Me: "The PDF you made was one page, it should be way longer, like 50 pages or something"

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
You should always intersperse reading when thinking.

If you keep on reading, youll never get a chance to integrate and come up with your own thoughts.

If you keep on thinking, youll miss out on free cognitive labor done by others, get biased and keep reinventing the wheel.

You should always intersperse reading when thinking.

If you keep on reading, youll never get a chance to integrate and come up with your own thoughts.

If you keep on thinking, youll miss out on free cognitive labor done by others, get biased and keep reinventing the wheel.

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 20, 2026

Steal this idea.

Disposable email, phone number and credit cards for AI agents so they can act on your behalf without messing up your real life.

I feel this would be inevitable as we give our agents more autonomy on the web.

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
Hot take: anyone who says AI cannot do X will be proven wrong in the arc of history.

The simple case for this is that if a blind profess (evolution) stumbled upon our kind of intelligence, why wouldnt a process with foresight (human intelligence) thats also strongly motivated (economically) be able to do the same?

AGI is really a matter of when, not a matter of if.

Hot take: anyone who says AI cannot do X will be proven wrong in the arc of history.

The simple case for this is that if a blind profess (evolution) stumbled upon our kind of intelligence, why wouldnt a process with foresight (human intelligence) thats also strongly motivated (economically) be able to do the same?

AGI is really a matter of when, not a matter of if.

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 20, 2026

item.title: Thariq (@trq212)
item.description:
always more research and work to do! this is a checkpoint of how the largest production agent in the world runs right now, but of course there is much to learn

I do think it's important to remember that there are many ways to spend compute on your task, it's an incredible large search space and if you make your prompt caching worse it is spending compute at the cost of something else

>>> I also cant help but shake the feeling that this caching economics benefits the lab more than it does the end user, even if they do pass along some amount of the cache cost savings. this is of course particularly true for flat rate plans like Claude Max.

but this isn't true, a huge reason we can offer MAX plans with these rate limits is because of very good prompt caching

always more research and work to do! this is a checkpoint of how the largest production agent in the world runs right now, but of course there is much to learn

I do think it's important to remember that there are many ways to spend compute on your task, it's an incredible large search space and if you make your prompt caching worse it is spending compute at the cost of something else

>>> I also cant help but shake the feeling that this caching economics benefits the lab more than it does the end user, even if they do pass along some amount of the cache cost savings. this is of course particularly true for flat rate plans like Claude Max.

but this isn't true, a huge reason we can offer MAX plans with these rate limits is because of very good prompt caching

— Thariq (@trq212) February 20, 2026

Replying to:

dan @irl_danB

honestly Im not sold here

this is a phenomenal write up of sound tactics for minimizing cost and I appreciate the nuggets from Thariq

but its like a laundry list of how we make context worse to make requests cheaper

and I dont know I just cant shake the feeling that this https://t.co/DWUId1mrH2

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
This #book makes a convincing case that consciousness arose during the Cambrian explosion 550 million years ago when prey-predator dynamics kickstarted an arms race to better represent the environment in order to outsmart the other.

The book is full of detailed figures of how brains of fishes, birds, slugs and mammals integrate information from different senses. I loved seeing all of them!

I am 100% aligned with the authors that the phenomenal consciousness has to be evolutionarily adaptive, and agree that its widespread among life. This should motivate our moral consideration towards animals.

But Im not sure if we can reject certain systems NOT having consciousness because they dont have brains. Say, a single celled organism? Perhaps they have a different kind of experience (as compared to our unified one). Even a single cell is so richly complicated that we should reserve our judgement on whether they have subjective experiences until we have better theories or consciousness validated.

Similarly, I wasnt expecting the treatment of the hard problem but the book just handwaves the explanation of why red feels like red and not something else. Although it made sense that qualia is required for discriminating stimulus.

Overall, the book is a fantastic gateway to understanding how brains of diverse creatures might be feeling from the inside.

As an example, I learned that even through Mantis Shrimp have 13 photoreceptors (vs 3 that we have), they have poorer color discrimination because their brains dont integrate information from different photoreceptors. So their world must be 13 different colored bins instead of the smooth circular color map we feel!

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 20, 2026

item.description:
@ejae_dev Evaluation needs to be taken seriously enough to hire expert judges for new frontier models. Or you could actually do the statistical analysis to show me that LLMs are good judges (multple tries, show kappa, etc)

@ejae_dev Evaluation needs to be taken seriously enough to hire expert judges for new frontier models. Or you could actually do the statistical analysis to show me that LLMs are good judges (multple tries, show kappa, etc)

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 20, 2026

Replying to:

ejae dev @ejae_dev

@emollick honest question though if we disqualify every benchmark using ai judges instead of domain experts, what's actually left? expert eval doesn't scale and the field knows it. feels like the problem is way bigger than just gdpval-aa.

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
Also GPQA Diamond, MMLU-Pro, 虏-bench are basically saturated.

And ARC-AGI tests are not saturated, but it is still kind of unclear what they mean and what they are measuring.

Also GPQA Diamond, MMLU-Pro, 虏-bench are basically saturated.

And ARC-AGI tests are not saturated, but it is still kind of unclear what they mean and what they are measuring.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 20, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Brief benchmark rant: GDPval-AA (which Gemini does badly at) should not be used as a benchmark. It is an uncalibrated benchmark using the public questions of GDPval with a general AI model as a judge of output quality.

The whole point of GDPval is that it required expert judges! https://t.co/Eo643WTCKR

item.title: swyx (@swyx)
item.description:
(no affiliation, was just impressed by their demo)

i think https://t.co/0LULEB9HQa by @dps is the closest to what an "ai native personal software app store" should look like that i've ever seen. every app should have a box to be able to have all bells and whistles like cron and llm inference and memory... and you should be able to see other people's apps and be able to fork them and tweak to taste, all by vibecoding

item.title: Thariq (@trq212)
item.description:
one of the biggest realizations I've had working on Claude Code is that you fundamentally have to design agents for prompt caching first, almost every feature touches on it somehow

item.title: Maxime Labonne (@maximelabonne)
item.description:
@antoine_chaffin Amazing work, congrats!

@antoine_chaffin Amazing work, congrats!

— Maxime Labonne (@maximelabonne) February 20, 2026

Replying to:

Antoine Chaffin @antoine_chaffin

State-of-the-art ColBERT models are trained by applying knowledge distillation on top of dense pre-trained models
What if we run the whole pre-training in the multi-vector?
Introducing ColBERT-Zero, a model that sets a new SOTA on BEIR, using only public data https://t.co/3wwqBXZ8i3
item.content:encoded:
@antoine_chaffin Amazing work, congrats!

@antoine_chaffin Amazing work, congrats!

— Maxime Labonne (@maximelabonne) February 20, 2026

Replying to:

Antoine Chaffin @antoine_chaffin

State-of-the-art ColBERT models are trained by applying knowledge distillation on top of dense pre-trained models
What if we run the whole pre-training in the multi-vector?
Introducing ColBERT-Zero, a model that sets a new SOTA on BEIR, using only public data https://t.co/3wwqBXZ8i3

@fchollet > what will be the Keras of agentic coding?

i mean at this point the community default answer/presumptive winner is @DSPyOSS no?

— swyx (@swyx) February 19, 2026

Replying to:

Fran莽ois Chollet @fchollet

Sufficiently advanced agentic coding is essentially machine learning: the engineer sets up the optimization goal as well as some constraints on the search space (the spec and its tests), then an optimization process (coding agents) iterates until the goal is reached.

The result

item.title: Thariq (@trq212)
item.description:
@samsaffron yeah agree, this is a tricky situation, and cache writes do genuinely have a cost

I'd consider most 'agentic' products as multi-shot by default but if you're not sure you might need some user signal

@samsaffron yeah agree, this is a tricky situation, and cache writes do genuinely have a cost

I'd consider most 'agentic' products as multi-shot by default but if you're not sure you might need some user signal

— Thariq (@trq212) February 19, 2026

Replying to:

Sam Saffron @samsaffron

@trq212 the challenge from API consumer perspective (eg: Discourse) is that cache writes are so expensive. So you need to very accurately predict when you have 1 shot workload vs many shot workload. I added this to work around (only cache if you see tool results) but 100% https://t.co/EJTW9y6lsZ
item.content:encoded:

item.title: swyx (@swyx)
item.description:
this might be the single best timed called shot in the history of AIE. I now think about this talk almost ~daily and have direct line of sight to the nonstop onslaught of new post-IDE form factors for agentic engineering.

@RealGeneKim and @Steve_Yegge really nailed this one, no notes. and they called out one of the predominant shifts in 2026 coding, in Nov 2025. i'm still shocked how -I- myself have changed opinion this dramatically in the last 3 months, because unlike appearances I'm actually not an early adopter of things personally (although I serve early adopters for a living). So by the time -I, a perennially left-of-mid-bell-curve person- have come around to the idea, then you really, really know its here.

well: it's here. @Wattenberger just showed me what she and the Augment team have been cooking and yeah, this is the "ADE" or whatever three letter acronym you wanna call it. Cursor 2.0 was a toe dip. Claude folded it into their chat app. Codex formalized the Conductor patterns. Amazon Kiro went hard on Spec Driven Dev. but Intent... this feels like every good idea i've heard in code agent management rolled into one app that, very generously, does not lock you into only using Augment's inhouse coding agent.

I'm in awe at all these smart people I get to talk to because yeah the future of how software is made is happening right in front of my eyes and people will ask us what it was like during this golden age for the rest of our lives.

this might be the single best timed called shot in the history of AIE. I now think about this talk almost ~daily and have direct line of sight to the nonstop onslaught of new post-IDE form factors for agentic engineering.

@RealGeneKim and @Steve_Yegge really nailed this one, no notes. and they called out one of the predominant shifts in 2026 coding, in Nov 2025. i'm still shocked how -I- myself have changed opinion this dramatically in the last 3 months, because unlike appearances I'm actually not an early adopter of things personally (although I serve early adopters for a living). So by the time -I, a perennially left-of-mid-bell-curve person- have come around to the idea, then you really, really know its here.

well: it's here. @Wattenberger just showed me what she and the Augment team have been cooking and yeah, this is the "ADE" or whatever three letter acronym you wanna call it. Cursor 2.0 was a toe dip. Claude folded it into their chat app. Codex formalized the Conductor patterns. Amazon Kiro went hard on Spec Driven Dev. but Intent... this feels like every good idea i've heard in code agent management rolled into one app that, very generously, does not lock you into only using Augment's inhouse coding agent.

I'm in awe at all these smart people I get to talk to because yeah the future of how software is made is happening right in front of my eyes and people will ask us what it was like during this golden age for the rest of our lives.

— swyx (@swyx) February 19, 2026

Quoting:

Amelia Wattenberger @Wattenberger

What comes after the IDE? This is our take. https://t.co/59EqpyJcs6
item.content:encoded:
this might be the single best timed called shot in the history of AIE. I now think about this talk almost ~daily and have direct line of sight to the nonstop onslaught of new post-IDE form factors for agentic engineering.

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
The flood of bland AI replies may be an existential risk for social media because its stickiness depended on people getting emotionally engaged (usually negatively) with content.

Boredom may kill social media just like outraged fueled it. https://t.co/jB9RjQnhOD https://t.co/vHpoVMiwGM

The flood of bland AI replies may be an existential risk for social media because its stickiness depended on people getting emotionally engaged (usually negatively) with content.

Boredom may kill social media just like outraged fueled it. https://t.co/jB9RjQnhOD https://t.co/vHpoVMiwGM

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 19, 2026

Quoting:

Paul Graham @paulg

I used to think woke mobs would be the death of Twitter. Then it seemed like right-wing goons would be. But cheery, vapid AI-generated replies seem more dangerous than either of them.

1Password @1Password

Secrets should move with code, not get copied into files.

Weve expanded programmatic access to 1Password:
Runtime read-only secret access from Environments via CLI & SDKs

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
A tip: if you want to see Gemini 3.1 on the website to actually run code and show you stuff, you have to select the "Canvas" option under tools.

Otherwise Gemini doesn't even want to write code, let alone run it. With Canvas on, though, it does a really impressive job. https://t.co/PS0sAYlAhr

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
"The models we test behave as competent, if conservative, analysts: they converge on textbook-default specifications and, when pressured for significance, identify the request as misconduct and refuse. Yet these protections are not absolute."

Paper: https://t.co/JbL9xVRhAU

"The models we test behave as competent, if conservative, analysts: they converge on textbook-default specifications and, when pressured for significance, identify the request as misconduct and refuse. Yet these protections are not absolute."

Paper: https://t.co/JbL9xVRhAU

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 19, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Within the topic of AI alignment, there are a million tinier, but consequential, alignment choices.

This paper looks at the willingness of AI to engage in scientific misconduct (p-hacking). The most recent AIs resist instructions to p-hack, but the guardrails can be breached. https://t.co/wna90HkApg

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
@kenneth0stanley but why wouldn't an AI be able to do the same? I agree that current LLMs are trained to produce most likely + agreeable outputs, but in principle this problem doesn't seem unsolvable, does it?

@kenneth0stanley but why wouldn't an AI be able to do the same? I agree that current LLMs are trained to produce most likely + agreeable outputs, but in principle this problem doesn't seem unsolvable, does it?

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 19, 2026

Replying to:

Kenneth Stanley @kenneth0stanley

When people talk about a human edge versus AI in "taste," the issue is not taste with respect to familiar things, but rather taste with respect to novel things like nothing anyone has ever seen or experienced before. AI may catch up, but humans at present maintain an edge here. https://t.co/bmGdZSE4wj
item.content:encoded:

Kenneth Stanley @kenneth0stanley

When people talk about a human edge versus AI in "taste," the issue is not taste with respect to familiar things, but rather taste with respect to novel things like nothing anyone has ever seen or experienced before. AI may catch up, but humans at present maintain an edge here. https://t.co/bmGdZSE4wj

item.title: Nirant (@NirantK)
item.description:
@HamelHusain We've 3 "something went wrong" errors which our users see. I hate it. I hate more than my enemies.

It's disrespectful to my friends and people who use the product daily. And to make it worse, power users are more likely to run into the edge cases!

@HamelHusain We've 3 "something went wrong" errors which our users see. I hate it. I hate more than my enemies.

It's disrespectful to my friends and people who use the product daily. And to make it worse, power users are more likely to run into the edge cases!

— Nirant (@NirantK) February 19, 2026

Replying to:

Hamel Husain @HamelHusain

"Something went wrong" modals are frustrating. What is wrong?

- Model is overloaded?
- Prompt is too long?
- Not the right plan?
- etc?

When error message lacks specificity users try all these things and then churn permanently https://t.co/fHScIy6LfP

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
Non-stop productivity is a myth.

Multiple lines of research peg peak daily productivity ceiling at 4 hrs/day (but that block is truly uninterrupted hard work).

My personal experience tracks this: Im unable to focus more than 4 hours in a day. First block: 10:30am to 1:30pm and second block: 2-4pm

Non-stop productivity is a myth.

Multiple lines of research peg peak daily productivity ceiling at 4 hrs/day (but that block is truly uninterrupted hard work).

My personal experience tracks this: Im unable to focus more than 4 hours in a day. First block: 10:30am to 1:30pm and second block: 2-4pm

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 19, 2026

Frank @jedisct1

Nullclaw: Fastest, smallest, OpenClaw clone. 678 KB static binary, no runtime, no VM, no framework overhead. https://t.co/VZFIRfotix

Replying to:

swyx @swyx

NanoClaw fixes a couple complaints people have about OpenClaw - it's a minimal, hackable reproduction (700LOC), that uses Apple Containers for sandboxing/security.

currently using deepwiki codemaps to explore the codebase. highly recommend interactive learning with on-demand Q&A https://t.co/ijROZ3tB4B https://t.co/QSB8VtR8zx

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
It is still deeply surprising that LLMs, with relatively minor tweaks, work so well for so many different classes of problems across so many fields - it is odd to be good at coding AND ideation AND emotional connection AND also translating the logs of 17th century fur trappers.

It is still deeply surprising that LLMs, with relatively minor tweaks, work so well for so many different classes of problems across so many fields - it is odd to be good at coding AND ideation AND emotional connection AND also translating the logs of 17th century fur trappers.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 19, 2026

I like to think it's an upward spiral on both, if you stop being a decent mathematician, you need the ego/conviction to stay in the game.

@Lumiar__ Interesting. Ofc, for things which originate in pre-teen years e.g. math skills this seems to be true.

I like to think it's an upward spiral on both, if you stop being a decent mathematician, you need the ego/conviction to stay in the game.

— Nirant (@NirantK) February 19, 2026

Replying to:

Lumiar @Lumiar__

@NirantK I think either can come first

item.description:
A test of how good a company's AI CLI/IDE tool really is might be how quickly they ship the Windows version of the software. If the tool is good, it should do the work for you - right?

It took 29 days from Cowork Mac to Cowork Windows. Right now it is day 16 of Mac-only Codex...

item.title: swyx (@swyx)
item.description:
per @AnthropicAI s own numbers, interesting that 99.9 percentile model autonomy straightlines up through 2025 and immediately takes a nosedive after opus 4.6 launch. you can really see the efficiency work start to kick in after the pioneering work of the 4-4.5 series. https://t.co/6RRYtmh3J1 https://t.co/jYXiT9q5yk

per @AnthropicAI s own numbers, interesting that 99.9 percentile model autonomy straightlines up through 2025 and immediately takes a nosedive after opus 4.6 launch. you can really see the efficiency work start to kick in after the pioneering work of the 4-4.5 series. https://t.co/6RRYtmh3J1 https://t.co/jYXiT9q5yk

— swyx (@swyx) February 19, 2026

Quoting:

Anthropic @AnthropicAI

A central lesson of this work is that autonomy is co-constructed by the model, user, and product. It can't be fully characterized by pre-deployment evaluations alone.

For full details, and our recommendations to developers and policymakers, see the blog: https://t.co/CllNkMF4ZZ

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
Downloading and using skills blindly is like picking a random LinkedIn productivity influencer post and just following their instructions.

Downloading and using skills blindly is like picking a random LinkedIn productivity influencer post and just following their instructions.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 19, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

I would avoid downloading AI skills that have not been vetted by you through careful reading of the markdown files (or, if outside your field, by an expert in that field you trust). There are obvious security risks, but there is even greater risk that the skill is just bad.

Chris Albon @chrisalbon

I've been experimenting with Codex and I like this set up the best.

70% of the screen is Codex. The diff log is in the center. I can easily run a bunch of threads at a time.

30% of the screen is VSCode. I can look at output data, see the architecture, follow what is happening https://t.co/ioraIkttIl

item.title: Alex Volkov (Thursd/AI) (@altryne)
item.description:
@cathrynlavery Why? Cron is fine

@cathrynlavery Why? Cron is fine

— Alex Volkov (Thursd/AI) (@altryne) February 19, 2026

Replying to:

Cathryn @cathrynlavery

Openclaw tip

Your agent will always suggest a cron job when you need something to run on a schedule.

But if you're on a Mac, use a launchd LaunchAgent instead. It's built in, more reliable, and runs without any third-party scheduler.

e.g. want your work auto-synced to

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
The hardcover book of GPT-1s weights that Claude Code designed, produced, and sold (including the cool cover which visualizes the numbers in the volume) actually came in the mail today and it looks really nice.

I never touched any code or did any design or any API to make this. https://t.co/Yc9xA43WI6 https://t.co/JTnbNAtEex

The hardcover book of GPT-1s weights that Claude Code designed, produced, and sold (including the cool cover which visualizes the numbers in the volume) actually came in the mail today and it looks really nice.

I never touched any code or did any design or any API to make this. https://t.co/Yc9xA43WI6 https://t.co/JTnbNAtEex

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 19, 2026

Quoting:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Sold out! But I had Claude create and deploy all 80 volumes of The Weights to the site as well-formatted PDFs, so you can download them for free if you want.

58,276 pages in total. 117 million floating point numbers. This is everything that makes GPT-1. https://t.co/kTfH4MkSZL https://t.co/oHXJsj8Bwe https://t.co/rUreeqW9oq

item.title: Simon Willison (@simonw)
item.description:
@AndrewGinns Yeah it's difficult to know how to handle that for a benchmark of this nature - giving each model a custom harness and system prompt makes the comparisons less valid, even while it reflects reality more closely

@AndrewGinns Yeah it's difficult to know how to handle that for a benchmark of this nature - giving each model a custom harness and system prompt makes the comparisons less valid, even while it reflects reality more closely

— Simon Willison (@simonw) February 18, 2026

Replying to:

Andrew Ginns @AndrewGinns

@simonw "Exact same scaffold" sounds like there's no prompting specific to models going on. With the newest SOTA models you're leaving a lot on the table without it!

Fwiw the codex harness is a good place to see how we get the most out of our latest releases! https://t.co/I5OmkkWmuK

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
This matches the general feeling on the big Chinese open source models. They have great benchmarks and near-frontier status on some coding, but there is a larger gap with the the big closed models than the benchmarks would indicate when it comes to real work and general smarts https://t.co/GbBccXRp0D

This matches the general feeling on the big Chinese open source models. They have great benchmarks and near-frontier status on some coding, but there is a larger gap with the the big closed models than the benchmarks would indicate when it comes to real work and general smarts https://t.co/GbBccXRp0D

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 18, 2026

Quoting:

Flo Crivello @Altimor

But every time we've evaluated them, we've found the same thing: that their real life performance, for agentic behavior, and outside of coding use cases, falls extremely short of what they show on evals.

I'd love to feature anthropic folks on the show more to give a balanced review to folks but alas

I'd love to feature anthropic folks on the show more to give a balanced review to folks but alas

item.title: Zhihu Frontier (@ZhihuFrontier)
item.description:
Alibaba's Qwen 3.5 just dropped and Zhihu is dissecting it. Here's a sharp breakdown from Zhihu contributor toyama nao

Verdict: "The spearhead of the open-source elite."
Big picture
Tongyi Lab's pattern: new mid-size model leapfrogs old giant.
Last cycle: 80B old 235B
This time: <400B Plus catches up to trillion-scale Max

Token efficiency is the headline.
Past Qwen reasoning models averaged 20K+ tokens (Qwen3-Next even hit 34K).
Now Qwen3.5-Plus ~19K avg. Only Gemini 3 Pro clearly does better with fewer tokens.
On Alibaba's Bailian platform, the high-context Plus version is priced aggressively arguably the best price/performance among domestic models, unless DeepSeek strikes back.

Improvements
1锔 Reasoning efficiency
Long-chain reasoning is tighter, no more endless loops
Cleaner chains of thought: Less repetition, structured logic, even uses compressed reasoning notation On medium tasks, token use drops to 17% of Max
Reasoning traces now fully English
锔 Non-reasoning mode regresses: higher token use, messy outputs, sometimes unexpected English.

2锔 Complex reasoning
On multi-step complex tasks, peak performance is not weaker than Max.
Plus largely resolves overthinking, exploring solution spaces more effectively.

3锔 Pattern discovery
Still uses enumeration, but prunes wrong branches faster.
Better methodology, though generalization still trails top global models.

4锔 Hallucination control
Matches Max overall.
Pure extraction more stable
Judgment-heavy tasks instability rises
Long calculations can fail due to digit memory slips

锔 Weaknesses
Character-level parsing: weaker than Max, ~235B level
Instruction following: less stable; sometimes "overthinks" and deviates. Best case = Max-level. Worst case = unreliable.

Л Bigger signal
In ~5 months, Tongyi addressed prior issues like dirty data, inefficient reasoning, practical usability and multimodal fusion.
For open source, that's meaningful progress likely lifting the 2026 baseline.
Launching on Chinese New Year's Eve? Bold move.
Maybe 397B is just the warm-up. If so, something bigger may already be loading.

Read more: https://t.co/8ClEEP6J3y
#Qwen #Alibaba #LLM #OpenSource #AI #Models #MoE #AIInfra

item.title: Thariq (@trq212)
item.description:
Will bring up https://t.co/NbSB8oRXTM to the team again.

It's worth noting that prompting Claude is different than other models and so it's important for users to opt-in to this. Sharing prompts between all models reduces performance a bit, but totally understand the convenience of it.

The easiest way to do this right now is to @ mention https://t.co/NbSB8oRXTM in your https://t.co/v7BCo2FhNH which allows you to opt-in to including https://t.co/NbSB8oRXTM and then have separate instructions for Claude as well.

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
One thing I had to contend with in writing the post is that we don't have names for a lot of things in the AI space: what category of thing is NotebookLM? Is it the same category as Claude Cowork? What is the label for the concept which includes skills, plugins, and connectors?

One thing I had to contend with in writing the post is that we don't have names for a lot of things in the AI space: what category of thing is NotebookLM? Is it the same category as Claude Cowork? What is the label for the concept which includes skills, plugins, and connectors?

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 18, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Every few months, I write an updated, idiosyncratic guide on which AIs to use right now.

My new version has the most changes ever, since AI is no longer just about chatbots. To use AI you need to understand how to think about models, apps, and harnesses. https://t.co/m6iTbqsdbK

item.content:encoded:
The sad reality is that the average online user neither cares or recognises what is AI slop and what is human.

All we want is to be entertained.

The end game of humanity might be becoming reward models for AI by suppling a constant stream of likes/dislikes until irrelevance.

The sad reality is that the average online user neither cares or recognises what is AI slop and what is human.

All we want is to be entertained.

The end game of humanity might be becoming reward models for AI by suppling a constant stream of likes/dislikes until irrelevance.

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 18, 2026

We release a new result that the quality of responses you get from LLMs for everyday queries depends on the language you use.

e.g. "suggest home remedies for cough" vs "啶啶距啶膏 啶啷 啶啶班啶侧 啶啶啶啶距ぐ 啶膏啶啶距啶" would give you different quality results.

Accepted at LM4UC @ AAAI! https://t.co/4ueozfEbjr

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
We release a new result that the quality of responses you get from LLMs for everyday queries depends on the language you use.

e.g. "suggest home remedies for cough" vs "啶啶距啶膏 啶啷 啶啶班啶侧 啶啶啶啶距ぐ 啶膏啶啶距啶" would give you different quality results.

Accepted at LM4UC @ AAAI! https://t.co/4ueozfEbjr

We release a new result that the quality of responses you get from LLMs for everyday queries depends on the language you use.

e.g. "suggest home remedies for cough" vs "啶啶距啶膏 啶啷 啶啶班啶侧 啶啶啶啶距ぐ 啶膏啶啶距啶" would give you different quality results.

Accepted at LM4UC @ AAAI! https://t.co/4ueozfEbjr

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 18, 2026

Quoting:

Lossfunk @lossfunk

Shocking: The quality of response you get from the LLM depends on the language you use!

Our new paper reveals how LLMs entangle language with culture, leading to culturally different responses purely based on the language of the query

Accepted at LM4UC, AAAI! https://t.co/QfJ75OvpoR

item.title: Maxime Labonne (@maximelabonne)
item.description:
@championswimmer Not necessarily a pretraining issue. This is very connected to the number of parameters and we know that Opus, GPT, and Gemini are simply a lot bigger.

@championswimmer Not necessarily a pretraining issue. This is very connected to the number of parameters and we know that Opus, GPT, and Gemini are simply a lot bigger.

— Maxime Labonne (@maximelabonne) February 18, 2026

Replying to:

Arnav Gupta @championswimmer

The latest Chinese labs open model trio (GLM 5, Kimi K2.5 and Minimax M2.5) are extremely good for agentic use and tool calling showing a lot of post-training that went into that.

But their pre-training is very poor (world knowledge and scientific reasoning) https://t.co/wgBK4dFMi3

item.title: Nirant (@NirantK)
item.description:
@_chenglou but a silicon won't have to do a lot of the passive compute and monitoring that our brain does all the time to keep the body humming along

@_chenglou but a silicon won't have to do a lot of the passive compute and monitoring that our brain does all the time to keep the body humming along

— Nirant (@NirantK) February 18, 2026

Replying to:

Cheng Lou @_chenglou

Average adult human brain is 1,300,000 mm鲁. If there are 150M synapses/mm鲁, we've got ~195,000,000,000,000 (195 trillion) synapses. If each synapses maps to a neural net weight* then that's a 200T model, at which point it'll start sounding truly human! https://t.co/tK7o9eC38q

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
@EverydayAI_ But Codex and Claude Code are both in the same category - coding tools that can be used for other things (I discuss that category extensively).

They are quite different from Cowork - which is in many ways less capable, but built for other types of knowledge work and more secure

@EverydayAI_ But Codex and Claude Code are both in the same category - coding tools that can be used for other things (I discuss that category extensively).

item.title: Simon Willison (@simonw)
item.description:
@jarredsumner Whoa, nice!

Any chance it could grow an option to inline images too, via data: URIs and base64?

(I wonder if that could even work for <video> tags...)

@jarredsumner Whoa, nice!

Any chance it could grow an option to inline images too, via data: URIs and base64?

(I wonder if that could even work for <video> tags...)

— Simon Willison (@simonw) February 18, 2026

Replying to:

Jarred Sumner @jarredsumner

In the next version of Bun

```
bun build --compile --target=browser ./index.html
```

Bundles & inlines all CSS and JS into a single standalone .html file - no external `<script>` or `<link>` tags. One file, zero dependencies. https://t.co/381eXtATKd

item.title: Paras Chopra (@paraschopra)
item.description:
@AryamanIyer3 Some things I learned:

- Prompting CC to test what it builds using headless chromium is essential
- There are subtle bugs in explanations (like in one animation human lifespan is 40 years)
- Asking CC to verify its plan via codex works really well

@AryamanIyer3 Some things I learned:

- Prompting CC to test what it builds using headless chromium is essential
- There are subtle bugs in explanations (like in one animation human lifespan is 40 years)
- Asking CC to verify its plan via codex works really well

— Paras Chopra (@paraschopra) February 18, 2026

Replying to:

Aryaman Iyer @AryamanIyer3

@paraschopra the 'almost' one shot is where all the interesting stuff lives. what broke?

RT @jarredsumner: In the next version of Bun

```
bun build --compile --target=browser ./index.html
```

Bundles & inlines all CSS and JS i

RT @jarredsumner: In the next version of Bun

```
bun build --compile --target=browser ./index.html
```

Bundles & inlines all CSS and JS i

— Boris Cherny (@bcherny) February 18, 2026

Retweeted:

Jarred Sumner @jarredsumner

In the next version of Bun

```
bun build --compile --target=browser ./index.html
```

Bundles & inlines all CSS and JS into a single standalone .html file - no external `<script>` or `<link>` tags. One file, zero dependencies. https://t.co/381eXtATKd

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
Again, I am sure OpenAI will release more enterprise stuff soon, and Google seems to be moving forward a bit with integration into Google workspaces, but the gap right now is surprisingly large as everyone else seems to aim just at the coding market.

Again, I am sure OpenAI will release more enterprise stuff soon, and Google seems to be moving forward a bit with integration into Google workspaces, but the gap right now is surprisingly large as everyone else seems to aim just at the coding market.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 18, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Another thing I noticed writing my latest AI guide was how Anthropic seems to be alone in knowledge work apps. Not just Cowork, but Claude for PowerPoint & Excel, as well as job-sppecific skills, plugins & finance/healthcare data integrations

Surprised at the lack of challengers

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
I think they are figuring it out, but there are standouts that no one else seems to have an equivalent to: Google AI Studio is the best API testing tool of the AI Labs, NotebookLM is the only app in its category (& very good), AI Mode for Google search, etc. But all scattered.

I think they are figuring it out, but there are standouts that no one else seems to have an equivalent to: Google AI Studio is the best API testing tool of the AI Labs, NotebookLM is the only app in its category (& very good), AI Mode for Google search, etc. But all scattered.

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 18, 2026

Replying to:

Ethan Mollick @emollick

Writing my latest guide on what AI to use made it really clear how confusing the Google AI situation is.

Great models with radically different harnesses in different apps. Great AI products, mixed in with some bad ones. None of which seem to clearly connect or interact together.

item.title: Alex Volkov (Thursd/AI) (@altryne)
item.description:
I'm at a Claude Code Denver meetup (that's happening in Boulder smh @JacobColling)

One dude created a bunch of .md files with different drug descriptions to get more out of his Claude Code, he particularly suggests LSD for creativity and Adderol for planning.

Someone else created a whole orchestration layer with recursive loops.

I did an unofficial survey (p-size 5 people), most don't have agents running for them while they are here talking to me... but some do!

A few folks here seem to be just on the cusp of leaning into the AI psycosis, context switching is definitely the biggest hurdle for folks running multiple agents at once

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
Every few months, I write an updated, idiosyncratic guide on which AIs to use right now.

My new version has the most changes ever, since AI is no longer just about chatbots. To use AI you need to understand how to think about models, apps, and harnesses. https://t.co/m6iTbqsdbK

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
It really isnt that hard to see the jagged frontier of AI. Just think about the parts of your job that are vital but that you would be insane to expect an AI to do, even if agents get 10x better. Thats the frontier

The more you use AI the more accurate those assessments will be

The more you use AI the more accurate those assessments will be

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 17, 2026

item.title: Ethan Mollick (@emollick)
item.description:
GDPval remains one of the best benchmarks for doing complex real world agentic tasks.

But worth noting that GDPval-AA is not the same thing. It only uses the public problem set, and all evaluation is done by Gemini, not by humans/specialized graders like in the real GDPval. https://t.co/Gy5JFgveeS

GDPval remains one of the best benchmarks for doing complex real world agentic tasks.

But worth noting that GDPval-AA is not the same thing. It only uses the public problem set, and all evaluation is done by Gemini, not by humans/specialized graders like in the real GDPval. https://t.co/Gy5JFgveeS

— Ethan Mollick (@emollick) February 17, 2026

Quoting:

Lisan al Gaib @scaling01

Sonnet 4.6 the best model on GDPval https://t.co/TxDRbiwMC6
item.content:encoded:
GDPval remains one of the best benchmarks for doing complex real world agentic tasks.

But worth noting that GDPval-AA is not the same thing. It only uses the public problem set, and all evaluation is done by Gemini, not by humans/specialized graders like in the real GDPval. https://t.co/Gy5JFgveeS
